newsitem.title: USA: Pioneer settles Crow's Hybrid suit.
newsitem.headline: Pioneer settles Crow's Hybrid suit.

text.p: Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc said Friday Crow's Hybrid Corn Co of Milford, Ill., has agreed to settle a suit brought against it by Pioneer.

Pioneer said it sued Crow's in 1994, alleging unlawful use of Pioneer brand hybrids and inbreds in its corn breeding and product development program. Crow's Hybrid contended the varieties in question had been developed from material purchased by Crow's in 1982, Pioneer said.
"We agreed to this settlement so that we could get back to doing what we do best -- selling hybrid seed," Kenneth Crow, president of Crow's Hybrid, said in a statement.

In addition to a monetary settlement, Crow's Hybrid has agreed to refrain from sales of certain hybrids that allegedly infringe on Pioneer's patents. It also agreed to refrain from the use or sale of any Pioneer germplasm that would knowingly violate any federal or state intellectual property laws, Pioneer said.
The amount of the monetary settlement was not disclosed.
Crow's Hybrid will continue to sell all other varieties, Pioneer said. Crow's Hybrid management also has agreed to identify and help secure the return of breeding material involving third parties.
Pioneer, a seed and agricultural biotech company, said it will invest over $130 million in research this year.
